content.full_text:
John E. Collins to Abraham Lincoln, 25 February 18491 Being desirous to annex myself to theU.S. Army. I would beg that you honor me with your nomination as Cadet atWest Point, if you have no prior Engagement. Or if the Vacancy of this District is not filled.

Your attention to this will recieve the warmest thanks of
paragraphs: John E. Collins to Abraham Lincoln, 25 February 18491 Being desirous to annex myself to theU.S. Army. I would beg that you honor me with your nomination as Cadet atWest Point, if you have no prior Engagement. Or if the Vacancy of this District is not filled.
Your attention to this will recieve the warmest thanks of
citations:
George Washington Cullum,Biographical Register of Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy from
                        1802 to 1867(Bedford, MA: Appleton Books, 2009), 651.

footnotes.text: 1John E. Collins wrote this letter in its entirety.

2On February 24, Collins penned a similarletterto Secretary of WarWilliam C. Marcyrequesting an appointment.  Abraham Lincolnâ€™s response to Collins, if he penned one,
                  has not been found.  There is no evidence that Collins either attended or graduated
                  from West Point.George Washington Cullum,Biographical Register of Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy from
                        1802 to 1867(Bedford, MA: Appleton Books, 2009), 651.

structured_content.text: John E. Collins to Abraham Lincoln, 25 February 18491

Being desirous to annex myself to theU.S. Army. I would beg that you honor me with your nomination as Cadet atWest Point, if you have no prior Engagement. Or if the Vacancy of this District is not filled.
               Your attention to this will recieve the warmest thanks of
